objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to introduce language interfaces, called SysCaps, for surrogate models of complex energy systems to make them more accessible and improve their accuracy and generalization abilities.
objective.evidence: Our work introduces the use of language descriptions, which we call 'system captions' or SysCaps, to interface with such surrogates. We argue that interacting with surrogates through text, particularly natural language, makes these models more accessible for both experts and non-experts.

knowledge_gap.answer: The paper addresses the gap in understanding whether textual inputs, particularly natural language inputs, are suitable for real-world tabular regression tasks in surrogate modeling.
knowledge_gap.evidence: In general, it is unknown whether textual inputs, and particularly natural language inputs, are suitable for real-world tabular regression tasks.

answer: Introduction of a lightweight multimodal surrogate model architecture for timeseries regression that fuses text embeddings with timeseries data.
Development of a process using LLMs to generate high-quality natural language SysCaps from simulation metadata.
Creation of an automatic evaluation strategy to assess caption quality by estimating the rate at which ground truth attributes appear in the synthetic description.
evidence: We introduce a simple and lightweight multimodal surrogate model architecture for timeseries regression that a) fuses text embeddings obtained from fine-tuned language models (LMs) with b) timeseries encoded by a bidirectional sequence encoder.
To address the lack of human-labeled natural language descriptions of complex systems, we describe a process that uses LLMs to generate high-quality natural language SysCaps from simulation metadata.

We develop an automatic evaluation strategy to assess caption quality–specifically, we estimate the rate at which ground truth attributes appear in the synthetic description with a multiclass attribute classifier.

inspirational_papers.answer:
- Lavin et al. (2021) Simulation intelligence: Towards a new generation of scientific methods. (Methodological precursors)
- Bhavsar et al. (2023) Machine learning surrogate of physics-based building-stock simulator for end-use load forecasting. (Experimental baselines)
- Zhang et al. (2021) High-resolution hourly surrogate modeling framework for physics-based large-scale building stock modeling. (Papers with limitations addressed by this work)
inspirational_papers.evidence: Data-driven surrogates enable computational scientists to efficiently predict the results of expensive numerical simulations that run on supercomputers (Lavin et al., 2021; Carter et al., 2023). Surrogates are particularly valuable for emulating simulations of complex energy systems (CES), which model dynamic interactions between humans, earth systems, and infrastructure. Examples of CES include buildings (Vazquez-Canteli et al., 2019; Dai et al., 2023; Bhavsar et al., 2023), electric vehicle fleets (Vepsäläinen et al., 2019), and microgrids (Du & Li, 2019).

limitations.name: Numerical Value Encoding
limitations.description: BERT-style tokenizers struggle with numerical values, affecting model performance.
limitations.evidence: Current BERT-style tokenizers struggle with numerical values (Wallace et al., 2019); for one example, they interpolate poorly to unseen numbers.

limitations.name: Logical Errors in SysCaps
limitations.description: LLMs may introduce logical errors in SysCaps, impacting model accuracy.
limitations.evidence: The LLM makes a subtle logical error here—the unoccupied heating temperature set point difference from occupied state suggests the set point should be lower by 10 degrees, not higher.
